findings.issue: Seismic design references ASCE/SEI 7 without specifying the edition. For California K-12 projects under DSA jurisdiction, CBC 2022 adopts ASCE 7-22. The specification must reference ASCE 7-22 explicitly to ensure compliance with current seismic requirements.
findings.existingText: Structural Performance:  Hangers and supports for HVAC piping and equipment shall withstand the effects of gravity loads and stresses within limits and under conditions indicated according to ASCE/SEI 7.
findings.replacementText: Structural Performance:  Hangers and supports for HVAC piping and equipment shall withstand the effects of gravity loads and stresses within limits and under conditions indicated according to ASCE/SEI 7-22 as adopted by CBC 2022.

findings.issue: Seismic restraint requirements mention designing seismic-restraint hangers and supports but do not reference DSA Interpretation of Regulations (IR) A-6, which is mandatory for DSA-jurisdiction projects. DSA IR A-6 specifies certification and documentation requirements for seismic bracing.
findings.replacementText: Seismic restraint design and certification shall comply with DSA IR A-6. Provide seismic certification documentation for all bracing components and assemblies. Where OSHPD pre-approval (OPA) products are used, submit OPA documentation.

findings.issue: Submittal requirements do not include seismic calculations and certification documentation per DSA IR A-6. For DSA projects, seismic restraint submittals must include calculations stamped by a California-licensed professional engineer and certification of compliance.
findings.replacementText: Seismic Restraint Submittals: Submit seismic restraint calculations signed and sealed by a California-licensed professional engineer. Include DSA IR A-6 certification forms and OSHPD pre-approval (OPA) documentation for pre-approved assemblies.

findings.issue: Fastener requirements do not address seismic loading or reference ICC-ES evaluation reports (ESR) for post-installed anchors in concrete. For DSA projects, anchors in seismic applications must comply with ACI 318 Chapter 17 and have valid ICC-ES reports.
findings.existingText: Mechanical-Expansion Anchors:  Insert-wedge-type, zinc-coated steel anchors, for use in hardened portland cement concrete; with pull-out, tension, and shear capacities appropriate for supported loads and building materials where used.
findings.replacementText: Mechanical-Expansion Anchors:  Insert-wedge-type anchors for use in hardened portland cement concrete, with current ICC-ES Evaluation Report (ESR) demonstrating compliance with ACI 318-19 Chapter 17 for seismic applications. Anchors shall have pull-out, tension, and shear capacities appropriate for supported loads including seismic forces per ASCE 7-22.

findings.issue: Pipe slope installation references ASME B31.9 for maximum deflections but does not address seismic movement allowances. Hangers must accommodate both thermal expansion and seismic displacement per ASCE 7-22 requirements.
findings.existingText: Pipe Slopes:  Install hangers and supports to provide indicated pipe slopes and to not exceed maximum pipe deflections allowed by ASME B31.9 for building services piping.
findings.replacementText: Pipe Slopes:  Install hangers and supports to provide indicated pipe slopes and to not exceed maximum pipe deflections allowed by ASME B31.9 for building services piping. Design hanger rod lengths and attachment points to accommodate seismic relative displacements per ASCE 7-22 Section 13.3.2.

findings.issue: AWS D1.1/D1.1M is referenced without a specific edition year. The current edition is AWS D1.1/D1.1M:2020. Specifying the edition ensures consistent application of welding requirements.
findings.existingText: Structural Steel Welding Qualifications:  Qualify procedures and personnel according to AWS D1.1/D1.1M, "Structural Welding Code - Steel."
findings.replacementText: Structural Steel Welding Qualifications:  Qualify procedures and personnel according to AWS D1.1/D1.1M:2020, "Structural Welding Code - Steel."

findings.issue: ASTM A 36/A 36M is referenced without edition year. While this is a stable standard, specifying the current edition (ASTM A36/A36M-19) provides clarity.
findings.existingText: Structural Steel:  ASTM A 36/A 36M, carbon-steel plates, shapes, and bars; black and galvanized.
findings.replacementText: Structural Steel:  ASTM A36/A36M-19, carbon-steel plates, shapes, and bars; black and galvanized.

findings.issue: Cadmium-plated steel is specified for pipe stand members. Cadmium plating is restricted due to toxicity concerns and is being phased out. Consider zinc or stainless-steel alternatives.
findings.existingText:
Vertical Members:  Two or more cadmium-plated-steel or stainless-steel, continuous-thread rods.
Horizontal Member:  Cadmium-plated-steel or stainless-steel rod with plastic or stainless-steel, roller-type pipe support.
findings.replacementText:
Vertical Members:  Two or more hot-dip galvanized steel or stainless-steel, continuous-thread rods.
Horizontal Member:  Hot-dip galvanized steel or stainless-steel rod with plastic or stainless-steel, roller-type pipe support.

findings.issue: Orphan editing note remains in the specification: 'Retain definitions remaining after this Section has been edited.' This note should be removed for final contract documents.
findings.existingText: Retain definitions remaining after this Section has been edited.

findings.issue: Orphan editing note remains: 'Trapeze pipe hanger in paragraph below requires calculating and detailing at each use.' This note should be removed.
findings.existingText: Trapeze pipe hanger in paragraph below requires calculating and detailing at each use.

findings.section: Multiple locations throughout Part 2 and Part 3
findings.issue: Multiple orphan editing notes remain throughout the specification (e.g., 'Verify suitability of fasteners...', 'Metal framing systems in this article require calculating...', etc.). These guidance notes should be removed from final contract documents. This applies throughout this section.
findings.existingText: Verify suitability of fasteners in this article for use in lightweight concrete...

findings.fileName: 230553 - IDENTIFICATION FOR HVAC PIPING AND EQUIPMENT.docx
findings.issue: Pipe labeling does not reference ASME A13.1 for hazardous materials identification. For K-12 facilities, proper hazard communication is required for any piping containing hazardous materials.
findings.replacementText: Hazardous Material Piping: Label piping containing hazardous materials in accordance with ASME A13.1 for color coding and legend requirements.

findings.fileName: 230553 - IDENTIFICATION FOR HVAC PIPING AND EQUIPMENT.docx
findings.issue: Chilled-water piping color schedule lists two letter colors (White and Black) which is inconsistent. Only one letter color should be specified.
findings.existingText:
Chilled-Water Piping:
Background Color:  Blue.
Letter Color:  White.
Letter Color:  Black.
findings.replacementText:
Chilled-Water Piping:
Background Color:  Blue.
Letter Color:  White.

findings.fileName: 230553 - IDENTIFICATION FOR HVAC PIPING AND EQUIPMENT.docx
findings.issue: Multiple orphan editing notes remain (e.g., 'In first paragraph below, describe required label content...'). These guidance notes should be removed from final contract documents. This applies throughout this section.
findings.existingText: In first paragraph below, describe required label content...

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: TAB contractor qualifications only reference AABC certification. NEBB (National Environmental Balancing Bureau) is an equally recognized certification body and should be included as an acceptable alternative for competitive bidding.
findings.existingText: TAB Contractor Qualifications:  Engage a TAB entity certified by AABC.
findings.replacementText: TAB Contractor Qualifications:  Engage a TAB entity certified by AABC or NEBB.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: Reference to ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1 is outdated. The standard is now published as ASHRAE 90.1 (IESNA was removed from the title). Additionally, Section 6.7.2.3 should be verified against the current edition adopted by California Energy Code.
findings.existingText: ASHRAE/IESNA Compliance:  Applicable requirements in ASHRAE/IESNA 90.1, Section 6.7.2.3 - "System Balancing."
findings.replacementText: ASHRAE 90.1 Compliance:  Applicable requirements in ASHRAE 90.1 as adopted by the California Energy Code, Section 6.7.2.3 - "System Balancing."

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.section: Part 3, Article 3.4 (General Procedures for Testing and Balancing)
findings.issue: Reference to SMACNA's 'HVAC Systems - Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing' should include edition year for clarity. Current edition is 2002 (with 2015 update).
findings.existingText: Perform testing and balancing procedures on each system according to the procedures contained in AABC's "National Standards for Total System Balance", ASHRAE 111, and SMACNA's "HVAC Systems - Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing" and in this Section.
findings.replacementText: Perform testing and balancing procedures on each system according to the procedures contained in AABC's "National Standards for Total System Balance" current edition, ASHRAE 111 current edition, and SMACNA's "HVAC Systems - Testing, Adjusting, and Balancing" (2002, with updates) and in this Section.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: Flow rate tolerances of plus or minus 10 percent are specified uniformly. ASHRAE 111 recommends tighter tolerances for outdoor air (plus or minus 10 percent of design minimum) to ensure adequate ventilation per ASHRAE 62.1. Consider adding specific outdoor air tolerance requirement.
findings.replacementText: Outdoor Airflow Rate: Plus 10 percent, minus 0 percent of design minimum outdoor airflow to ensure minimum ventilation requirements per ASHRAE 62.1 are met.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: Orphan editing note remains: 'Retain definition(s) remaining after this Section has been edited.' This note should be removed.
findings.existingText: Retain definition(s) remaining after this Section has been edited.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: Bracketed options remain unresolved throughout the document (e.g., '[Architect] [Owner] [Construction Manager] [Commissioning Authority]'). While handled separately per instructions, these appear extensively and indicate the specification has not been project-customized.
findings.existingText: [Architect] [Owner] [Construction Manager] [Commissioning Authority]
findings.replacementText: Architect

findings.issue: Surface burning characteristics reference ASTM E 84 but do not address California's specific requirements. For California K-12 projects, materials must also comply with California State Fire Marshal requirements and Title 19 CCR.
findings.replacementText: Comply with California State Fire Marshal requirements and Title 19 CCR for interior finish materials in educational occupancies.
findings.codeReference: Title 19 CCR, California State Fire Marshal

findings.issue: Fire-rated insulation for kitchen hood exhaust references 1 or 2-hour ratings but does not specify compliance with CMC or California Fire Code requirements for Type I hood exhaust ductwork. CMC Section 507.2 requires specific construction for grease ducts.
findings.existingText: Fire-Rated Board:  Structural-grade, press-molded, xonolite calcium silicate, fireproofing board suitable for operating temperatures up to 1700 deg F.  Comply with ASTM C 656, Type II, Grade 6.  Tested and certified to provide a [1] [2]-hour fire rating by an NRTL acceptable to authorities having jurisdiction.
findings.replacementText: Fire-Rated Board:  Structural-grade, press-molded, xonolite calcium silicate, fireproofing board suitable for operating temperatures up to 1700 deg F.  Comply with ASTM C 656, Type II, Grade 6.  Tested and certified to provide the fire rating required by CMC Section 507.2 and California Fire Code by an NRTL acceptable to authorities having jurisdiction.

findings.issue: ASTM C 533 is referenced for calcium silicate insulation. The current designation is ASTM C533-19. Additionally, compressive strength is stated as '100-psig' but should be '100 psi' as compressive strength is not a gauge pressure measurement.
findings.existingText: ASTM C 533, Type I calcium silicate with 100-psig minimum compressive strength.
findings.replacementText: ASTM C533-19, Type I calcium silicate with 100 psi minimum compressive strength.

findings.issue: MIL-A-3316C is referenced but this military specification was cancelled in 2016. Industry has transitioned to ASTM C1696 for insulation adhesives.
findings.existingText: Mineral-Fiber Adhesive:  Comply with MIL-A-3316C, Class 2, Grade A.
findings.replacementText: Mineral-Fiber Adhesive:  Comply with ASTM C1696, Type I.

findings.issue: MIL-A-3316C reference is obsolete (cancelled 2016). Update to current ASTM standard.
findings.existingText: Description:  Comply with MIL-A-3316C, Class I, Grade A and shall be compatible with insulation materials, jackets, and substrates.
findings.replacementText: Description:  Comply with ASTM C1696, Type II and shall be compatible with insulation materials, jackets, and substrates.

findings.issue: Fire-rated penetration reference has a typo: 'Section 078413 "Penetration Firestopping"irestopping' should be corrected.
findings.existingText: Comply with requirements in Section 078413 "Penetration Firestopping"irestopping and fire-resistive joint sealers.
findings.replacementText: Comply with requirements in Section 078413 "Penetration Firestopping" for firestopping and fire-resistive joint sealers.

findings.section: Multiple locations throughout Part 2 and Part 3
findings.issue: Multiple orphan editing notes remain throughout the specification (e.g., 'In first subparagraph below, many manufacturers do not recommend...', 'Retain ASTM C 1290 types as follows...'). These guidance notes should be removed from final contract documents. This applies throughout this section.
findings.existingText: In first subparagraph below, many manufacturers do not recommend 100 percent coverage...

findings.issue: Flexible elastomeric insulation temperature limits are stated in editing notes but the actual specification does not state the temperature limits. For refrigerant piping applications, verify that the specified insulation is suitable for the expected operating temperatures.
findings.replacementText: Service Temperature Range: Minus 40 deg F to plus 220 deg F. Verify suitability for refrigerant suction line temperatures.

findings.issue: Insulation thickness requirements should reference California Energy Code (Title 24, Part 6) minimum pipe insulation requirements rather than relying solely on ASHRAE 90.1. California Energy Code may have more stringent requirements.
findings.replacementText: Pipe insulation thickness shall comply with California Energy Code (Title 24, Part 6) Table 120.3-A minimum requirements or the thicknesses specified herein, whichever is greater.
findings.codeReference: California Energy Code Title 24 Part 6, Table 120.3-A

findings.issue: MIL-A-3316C is referenced but this military specification was cancelled in 2016. Industry has transitioned to ASTM C1696 for insulation adhesives. This issue applies to multiple adhesive paragraphs in this section.
findings.existingText: Mineral-Fiber Adhesive:  Comply with MIL-A-3316C, Class 2, Grade A.
findings.replacementText: Mineral-Fiber Adhesive:  Comply with ASTM C1696, Type I.

findings.issue: MIL-A-24179A is referenced for flexible elastomeric adhesive but this specification is obsolete. Manufacturer's recommended adhesive should be specified instead.
findings.existingText: Flexible Elastomeric and Polyolefin Adhesive:  Comply with MIL-A-24179A, Type II, Class I.
findings.replacementText: Flexible Elastomeric and Polyolefin Adhesive:  Manufacturer's recommended contact adhesive specifically formulated for flexible elastomeric insulation.

findings.issue: Chilled water insulation specifies only 1-inch mineral fiber which may not meet California Energy Code requirements for all pipe sizes. Title 24 Part 6 Table 120.3-A requires varying thicknesses based on pipe size and fluid temperature.
findings.existingText: Mineral-Fiber, Preformed Pipe, Type I:  1 inch thick.
findings.replacementText: Mineral-Fiber, Preformed Pipe, Type I:  Thickness per California Energy Code Title 24 Part 6 Table 120.3-A, but not less than 1 inch for pipes NPS 1-1/4 and smaller, 1-1/2 inches for NPS 1-1/2 to NPS 4, and 2 inches for NPS 5 and larger.

findings.issue: Refrigerant suction piping insulation at 1-inch thickness may be inadequate to prevent condensation in high-humidity environments typical in California. Consider increased thickness or specify based on dew point analysis.
findings.existingText: Flexible Elastomeric:  1 inch thick.
findings.replacementText: Flexible Elastomeric:  1-1/2 inches thick minimum, or thickness required to maintain outer surface temperature above ambient dew point, whichever is greater.

findings.issue: Multiple orphan editing notes remain throughout the specification (e.g., 'Retain this article to require shipping container markings...', 'Product attributes in first paragraph below are based on Foster Brand products...'). These guidance notes should be removed from final contract documents. This applies throughout this section.
findings.existingText: Retain this article to require shipping container markings...

findings.issue: The specification lists an exhaustive catalog of MSS SP-58 hanger types (Types 1-58) with detailed application criteria. While comprehensive, this level of detail is excessive for most projects and creates unnecessary complexity. A simplified approach referencing MSS SP-69 for selection guidance with key types identified would be more practical and reduce specification length significantly.
findings.existingText: Horizontal-Piping Hangers and Supports:  Unless otherwise indicated and except as specified in piping system Sections, install the following types: [extensive list of 20+ MSS types]...
findings.replacementText: Horizontal-Piping Hangers and Supports: Select hanger and support types per MSS SP-69 recommendations for the piping system and conditions. Commonly used types include MSS Types 1, 3, 4, 5, 7, and 24 for horizontal piping and Types 8 and 42 for risers.

findings.fileName: 230593 - TESTING, ADJUSTING, AND BALANCING FOR HVAC.docx
findings.issue: The final report requirements are extraordinarily detailed, requiring specific data points for every piece of equipment down to belt sizes and sheave bore dimensions. While thorough documentation is important, this level of detail creates excessive paperwork burden without proportional benefit for typical K-12 projects. Consider streamlining to essential performance data.
findings.existingText: Air-Handling-Unit Test Reports:  For air-handling units with coils, include the following: [extensive multi-page list of data points]...
findings.replacementText: Air-Handling-Unit Test Reports: Include unit identification, location, design versus actual airflows and static pressures, motor voltage and amperage, and coil performance data (temperatures, pressures, flow rates). Additional detail per AABC or NEBB standard report formats.
